section.title: Present Perfect Simple and Continuous
section.sectiontitle: Use the Present Perfect Simple to talk about an action or experience in the past when the time is not important or not known.
section.text1a: I've visited several countries in South America.
section.sectiontitle2: Use the Present Perfect Simple to describe an action that started in the past and continues in the present, when the focus is on the finished action or on the number of times the action has been completed up to the time of speaking.
section.text4a: You've told me that three times this morning.

section.title: Present Perfect Simple and Continuous
section.sectiontitle: Use the Present Perfect Simple to describe an action that happened in the past but has the result in the present.
section.text1a: The post has come. There's a letter for you.
section.text2a: I've made some supper. It's on the table.
section.sectiontitle2: Use the Present Perfect Continuous to describe an action that started in the past and continues in the present, when the focus is on the activity itself.
section.text3a: She's exhausted. She's been ironing all morning.
section.text4a: He's been playing tennis for three hours.

section.title: Present Perfect Simple and Continuous
section.sectiontitle: Just means a short time ago. It usually comes between has / have and the past participle.
section.text2a: We've just got back from our holiday.
section.sectiontitle2: Already shows that something happened sooner than expected. It usually comes between has / have and the past participle or at the end of the sentence.
section.text3a: We've already seen that DVD. Let's choose another one.
section.text4a: You don't need to do the shopping. I've done it already.

section.title: Present Perfect Simple and Continuous
section.sectiontitle: Yet shows that the speaker expected something to happen before now. It is used at the end of negatives and questions.
section.text1a: She hasn't replied to the invitation yet.
